stream_context.summary: Kaze livestreams modelling and layout work for the first overworld of “Return to Yoshi’s Island.”  The focus is on adding giant fruit set-pieces (orange, banana, grapes) and refining the island’s pathing so that travel feels tight but not empty.  He also reflects on a morning of technical fixes (re-importing Course 6), discusses a forthcoming Fast64 update, and confirms a new pause-menu map-warp system that will replace conventional fast-travel passages.

development_findings.summary: Re-importing every asset of Course 6 with the current Fast64 pipeline unexpectedly fixed multiple long-standing engine bugs.
development_findings.quote: I spent all morning re-importing all the assets from course 6… somehow that fixed a bunch of bugs with course 6.

development_findings.summary: Old Fast64 conversion output is now considered incompatible with the custom engine; anything exported before ~2023 may need re-export.
development_findings.quote: The level was last exported 2022 so that seems unlikely… something about the old way of Fast64 conversion must have been completely incompatible with the engine.

development_findings.summary: Kaze plans a pause-menu map that lets players warp to any previously entered level entrance, eliminating overworld back-tracking.
development_findings.quote: On the map you can select which level entrance you walk to… there would be no travel time.

development_findings.summary: Certain overworld stretches are being physically shortened to reduce ‘vast empty land’ after adding the warp system.
development_findings.quote: Maybe this straight here is a little long… we should shorten that.

development_findings.summary: A red-coin switch gimmick is planned: pressing it spawns coins that form a short platforming challenge among the fruits.
development_findings.quote: The idea here was that you could hit a red coin switch and then red coins would appear and you have to platform through them.

development_findings.summary: Kaze experimented with N64-style material settings (shade color, primitive color, reflection combiner) to fake orange peel highlights but may fall back to a simple normal map.
development_findings.quote: I might have to say no to the reflection idea… too bad.

development_findings.summary: He confirmed the code for ‘fancy water graphics’ is ready and will be applied later.
development_findings.quote: Will you be giving this area fancy water graphics too? – Yes. We already have the codes.

development_findings.summary: Rope physics already exist in the codebase but are not yet applied to poles; he is debating enabling them to make ropes feel less rigid.
development_findings.quote: We have rope physics already. I just haven't applied them to any poles… maybe I should.

development_findings.summary: Lilaa’s new ‘export-label workaround’ lets Kaze skip manual label requests during asset exports.
development_findings.quote: I implemented my export label workaround today. I will no longer ask for export labels.

development_findings.summary: He uses a newly discovered Blender plug-in (found by Biobak) to instantly straighten UVs, speeding up fruit modelling.
development_findings.quote: Mushy, you should have seen this earlier when I used this button… you have no idea how convenient these buttons are.

context_findings.summary: Kaze was late to stream after talking with his mother and will leave early for sushi, showing ongoing effort to balance family, work, and rest.
context_findings.quote: Did everyone think I wasn’t gonna stream today because I was late… after stream I’m gonna be out for sushi.

context_findings.summary: He is highly smell-sensitive (vinegar cleaning made the room ‘unbearable’) and generally dislikes strawberry shortcake due to a bad personal memory.
context_findings.quote: Zayna cleaned the coffee machine with vinegar yesterday and it was unbearable living in that room.

context_findings.summary: Shows self-awareness about accessibility, adding a ‘cheat’ option so even ‘bad players can play the game.’
context_findings.quote: It’s an accessibility option… figured we should make it so that even bad players can play the game.

context_findings.summary: Expresses a design philosophy that in Pokémon (and games generally) the true resource is player time—a lens he applies to his own level-flow decisions.
context_findings.quote: Players don’t realize the only resource they truly have is their time… as soon as you realize that, Pokémon kind of sucks.

biobak.summary: Discovered and shared a UV-straightening Blender plug-in that Kaze now relies on for rapid asset cleanup.
biobak.quote: This is a very cool plug-in that Biobak found.

badub.summary: Confirmed as lead composer; actively in chat and producing original music for the hack.

zeina.summary: Performed off-stream task of cleaning the coffee machine, incidentally affecting Kaze’s work environment.
zeina.quote: Zayna cleaned the coffee machine with vinegar yesterday and it was unbearable.

key_stories.title: Course 6 Bug Exorcism
key_stories.summary: Legacy exports of Course 6 were causing mysterious engine bugs.  Kaze re-exported every asset with the modern Fast64 toolchain and the problems vanished.
key_stories.challenge: Persistent Course 6 glitches traced to unknown causes.
key_stories.process: Re-imported all geometry and assets using up-to-date Fast64 settings.
key_stories.outcome: Level now functions cleanly; old exporter deemed incompatible.
key_stories.key_quote: Somehow that fixed a bunch of bugs with course 6.

key_stories.title: Map-Warp Pivot
key_stories.summary: Initial plan for physical fast-travel paths felt slow.  Kaze replaced it with a pause-menu map that lets players warp to unlocked entrances, freeing him to shorten or remove empty terrain.
key_stories.process: Brainstormed, then committed to menu-based warping; began trimming geography.
key_stories.outcome: Travel time eliminated; overworld now optimized for density, not distance.
key_stories.key_quote: There would be no travel time, so I’m actually not worried about travel time at all.

key_stories.title: The Impossible Orange
key_stories.summary: Kaze spent considerable time trying to make a convincing N64-style orange model, juggling reflection combiners, shade colors, and texture searches.
key_stories.challenge: N64 hardware limitations made realistic citrus skin hard to fake.
key_stories.process: Iterated through multiple textures and combiner setups; considered normal mapping.
key_stories.outcome: Settled on a temporary texture; reflection idea postponed for practicality.
key_stories.key_quote: Dude, I can’t make a fucking orange… oh well, this is what it’s gonna be for now.
